| established_date1               = June 8, 2020
| established_title2              = 
| established_date2               = 
| footnotes                       = 
| official_name                   = 
}}
{{Campaignbox George Floyd protests}}
The '''Capitol Hill Autonomous Zone''' ('''CHAZ'''),<ref name="PPPC">{{cite web |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/seattle-protesters-set-autonomous-zone-after-police-evacuate-precinct-n1230151 |title=Seattle protesters set up 'autonomous zone' after police evacuate precinct |publisher=[[NBC News]] |date=June 11, 2020 |accessdate=12 June 2020 |last1=Silva |first1=Daniella |last2=Moschella |first2=Matteo }}</ref> also known as '''Free Capitol Hill'''<ref name="Stranger2"/><ref name="Stranger"/> and referred to as the '''Capitol Hill Organized Protest'''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/seattle-capitol-hill-autonomous-zone-visited-by-violent-proud-boys?ref=home |title=The Far Right Is Stirring Up Violence at Seattle's Capitol Hill Autonomous Zone |date=June 16, 2020 |accessdate=June 17, 2020 |website=[[The Daily Beast]] |last=Weill |first=Kelly}}</ref> and the '''Capitol Hill Occupied Protest''' ('''CHOP'''),<ref name="CHOPCNN">{{cite web |url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/06/15/us/seattle-capitol-hill-autonomous-zone-monday/index.html |title=Protesters have occupied part of Seattle's Capitol Hill for a week. Here's what it's like inside |publisher=[[CNN]] |date=15 June 2020 |accessdate=15 June 2020 |last1=Simon |first1=Dan |last2=Reeve |first2=Elle |last3=Silverman |first3=Hollie}}</ref><ref name="CHOP"/><ref name="CHOPEEE">{{cite web |url=https://www.seattlepi.com/seattlenews/article/What-is-CHOP-the-zone-in-Seattle-formed-by-15341281.php |title=How CHAZ became CHOP: Seattle's police-free zone explained |work=[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]] |date=15 June 2020 |accessdate=15 June 2020 |author=Savransky, Becca |quote=Known as the Capitol Hill Autonomous Zone (CHAZ) at first, several protesters in the area made a push for the name to better reflect its purpose and renamed the roughly six-block area. CHOP, the new acronym, now stands for the Capitol Hill Organized (or Occupied) Protest.}}</ref> is an [[Occupation (protest)|occupation protest]] and self-declared [[permanent autonomous zone|autonomous zone]]<ref name="SelfDeclared01">{{cite news|last=Rambaran|first=Vandana|date=10 June 2020|title=Seattle protesters storm City Hall, demand mayor resign after driving police out of area, declaring autonomous zone|publisher=Fox News|location=|url=https://www.foxnews.com/us/seattle-city-hall-protesters-autonomous-zone|url-status=live|access-date=10 June 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200610180745/https://www.foxnews.com/us/seattle-city-hall-protesters-autonomous-zone|archive-date=June 10, 2020|quote=The protesters continued to camp out in a self-declared “Capitol Hill Autonomous Zone” (CHAZ)-- a region spanning six blocks and encompassing the precinct}}</ref> in the [[Capitol Hill (Seattle)|Capitol Hill]] neighborhood of [[Seattle]], [[Washington (state)|Washington]]. The zone, originally covering six city blocks and a park,<ref name="Heavy">{{cite news |last1=Dwilson |first1=Stephanie Dube |title='You're Now Leaving the USA': Capitol Hill Autonomous Zone Declared in Seattle |url=https://heavy.com/news/2020/06/capitol-hill-autonomous-zone-chaz/ |work=Heavy |date=June 10, 2020 |access-date=June 10, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200610094710/https://heavy.com/news/2020/06/capitol-hill-autonomous-zone-chaz/ |archive-date=June 10, 2020 |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name="City Journal">{{Cite web|last=Rufo|first=Christopher F.|date=June 10, 2020|title=Anarchy in Seattle|url=https://www.city-journal.org/antifa-seattle-capitol-hill-autonomous-zone|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200611021201/https://www.city-journal.org/antifa-seattle-capitol-hill-autonomous-zone|archive-date=June 11, 2020|accessdate=11 June 2020|work=[[City Journal]]}}</ref> was established on June 8, 2020 by [[George Floyd protests|George Floyd protesters]] after the [[Seattle Police Department]] (SPD) vacated its East Precinct building.<ref name="KIRO-Jun9" />

Local governance in the zone is decentralized, with the goal of creating a neighborhood without [[police]]. Purported demands associated with the zone include [[Rent Control|rent control]], the reversal of [[gentrification]], the [[Police abolition movement|abolition]] or [[Defund the police|defunding]] of police, funding of [[community health]], and releasing prisoners serving time for [[Cannabis (drug)|marijuana]]-related offenses or resisting arrest, with [[expungement]] of their records.<ref name="Daily Dot demands"/><ref name="Newsweek demands"/>

Reactions to the zone have varied through the political spectrum. [[President of the United States|President]] [[Donald Trump]] referred to the occupants as "ugly [[anarchism|Anarchists]]" and called for the governor of Washington and the mayor of Seattle to "take back" the zone,<ref name="WaPost-Trump"/> while [[Mayor of Seattle|Mayor]] [[Jenny Durkan]] on June 11 described the zone as "four blocks in Seattle that is more like a block party atmosphere. It's not an armed takeover. It's not a [[military junta]]. We will make sure that we will restore this but we have block parties and the like in this part of Seattle all the time{{nbsp}}... there is no threat right now to the public."<ref name="auto">{{cite web |url=https://heavy.com/news/2020/06/seattle-autonomous-zone-videos-what-its-like-inside-the-chaz/ |title=Seattle Autonomous Zone Videos: What It's Like Inside the CHAZ |publisher=[[Heavy.com]] |date=June 12, 2020 |accessdate=June 12, 2020 |author=McBride, Jessica}}</ref> On June 14, ''[[USA Today]]'' confirmed the festive atmosphere, reporting that protesters who had previously clashed with police "have had their rough edges dulled by tens of thousands of tourists and sightseers. CHAZ has morphed into what looks and feels like a mini [[Burning Man]] festival."<ref name="USA Today in the Zone"/>

Following the zone's founding, SPD Chief [[Carmen Best]] said that the police department was looking at different approaches to "reduce [their] footprint" in the Capitol Hill neighborhood<ref name="KIROFM"/> but later said that officials were working to return police officers to the precinct. She stressed the "need to have officers responding to calls in a timely fashion. And with the occupation that's taking place, we're not able to do so in a timely way."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://apnews.com/dbec74a55889d6e7d674fe03773922fb |title=Q&A: What's next for Seattle protesters' 'autonomous zone'? |publisher=[[Associated Press]] |date=June 12, 2020 |accessdate=June 12, 2020 |author=Grygiel, Chris}}</ref> On June 14, Chief Best spoke of having marched with [[Black Lives Matter]] (BLM) in the zone two days before: "I was looking at the 60,000 people that were there, signs saying, you know, defund the police, stop police brutality, you know, no qualified immunity. [...] And I just realized it was a moment, an epiphany, that this is a pivotal moment in history. We are going to move in a different direction and policing will never be the same as it was before."<ref name="Best policing never be the same">{{cite web |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/transcript-chief-carmen-best-on-face-the-nation-june-14-2020/ |title=Transcript: Chief Carmen Best on "Face the Nation," June 14, 2020 |publisher=[[CBS News]] |date=June 14, 2020 |accessdate=June 14, 2020}}</ref>

On June 12, BLM protesters were reportedly negotiating with local officials to leave the zone.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/seattle-protesters-negotiate-over-leaving-autonomous-zone-11591987159 |title=Seattle Protesters Negotiate Over Leaving 'Autonomous Zone' |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |date=June 12, 2020 |accessdate=June 12, 2020 |author=Carlton, Jim}}</ref> Four days later, the zone's roadblocks were replaced and moved,<ref>{{Cite web|date=2020-06-16|title=Seattle shrinks CHOP area with street barriers|url=https://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/seattle-transportation-crew-shrinks-capitol-hill-protest-area-with-street-barriers/|access-date=2020-06-16|website=The Seattle Times|language=en-US}}</ref> allowing for emergency service vehicles to pass through and decreasing CHAZ's size to 3 blocks.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Wallace|first=Danielle|date=2020-06-16|title=Seattle reaches deal with 'CHOP' to remove temporary roadblocks, replace with concrete barriers|url=https://www.foxnews.com/us/seattle-deal-chop-temporary-roadblocks|access-date=2020-06-16|website=Fox News|language=en-US}}</ref>

== Background ==
[[File:Seattle East Precinct Sign under Capitol Hill Autonomous Zone.jpg|thumb|left|The SPD East Precinct building's sign on June 10, 2020. The building, boarded up and abandoned, shows "people" [[spray painted]] over the word "police."|alt=]]
[[Capitol Hill (Seattle)|Capitol Hill]] is a district in [[downtown Seattle]] known for its prominent [[LGBT]] and [[counterculture]] communities. The district was previously a center for other mass protests,<ref>{{cite news |last1=Banel |first1=Feliks |title=Long history of racial and economic unrest in Seattle |url=https://mynorthwest.com/1919707/history-racial-economic-unrest-seattle/ |accessdate=June 10, 2020 |work=MyNorthwest |date=June 5, 2020}}</ref> such as the [[1999 Seattle WTO protests]]<ref>{{Cite web|last=Burton|first=Lynsi|date=2014-11-29|title=WTO riots in Seattle: 15 years ago|url=https://www.seattlepi.com/seattlenews/article/WTO-riots-in-Seattle-15-years-ago-5915088.php|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-06-17|website=[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]}}</ref> and [[Occupy Seattle]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Occupy Seattle protesters clash with police on Capitol Hill |url=https://www.seattletimes.com/news/occupy-seattle-protesters-clash-with-police-on-capitol-hill/ |accessdate=June 10, 2020 |work=The Seattle Times |date=November 2, 2011}}</ref>

[[George Floyd protests in Washington (state)|Protests]] over the [[killing of George Floyd]] and [[Police brutality in the United States|police brutality]] began in Seattle on May 29, 2020.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://q13fox.com/2020/05/29/downtown-storefront-smashed-as-george-floyd-protesters-take-to-downtown-seattle-streets/ |title=George Floyd protesters take to downtown Seattle streets; 7 arrested |publisher=[[KCPQ]] |date=May 29, 2020 |accessdate=June 17, 2020}}</ref> For nine days there were street clashes involving protesters, the Seattle Police Department (SPD), [[Washington State Patrol]], and [[Washington National Guard]].<ref>{{Cite web|last=Kamb|first=Lewis|date=2020-06-09|title=How ambiguity and a loophole undermined Seattle's ban on tear gas during George Floyd demonstrations|url=https://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/how-ambiguity-and-a-loophole-undermined-seattles-ban-on-tear-gas-during-george-floyd-demonstrations/|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-06-17|work=[[The Seattle Times]]|quote=Between May 30 and June 4, an average of about 71 WSP troopers assisted Seattle police during demonstrations in the city. … Groups of Washington National Guard soldiers, ranging from 74 soldiers on May 31 to 600 soldiers on June 6 and 7, also have been deployed to Seattle at the request of Seattle's Emergency Operations Center and with the governor's authorization.}}</ref> On June 5, [[Mayor of Seattle|Mayor]] [[Jenny Durkan]] and SPD Chief [[Carmen Best]] announced a 30-day ban on the use of [[tear gas]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Kamb |first1=Lewis |last2=Beekman |first2=Daniel |title=Seattle mayor, police chief agree to ban use of tear gas on protesters amid ongoing demonstrations |url=https://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/watchdog-groups-to-seattles-mayor-and-police-chief-spd-should-stop-using-tear-gas-on-demonstrators/ |work=The Seattle Times |date=June 5, 2020 |access-date=June 11, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200611041741/https://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/watchdog-groups-to-seattles-mayor-and-police-chief-spd-should-stop-using-tear-gas-on-demonstrators/ |archive-date=June 11, 2020 |url-status=live }}</ref> Protests eventually coalesced around the SPD's East Precinct building, where the SPD used aggressive dispersal tactics, including [[blast ball]]s,<ref>{{cite news |last1=Jones |first1=Liz |last2=Raftery |first2=Isolde |title=This 26-year-old 'died three times' after police hit her with a blast ball |url=https://www.kuow.org/stories/this-26-year-old-died-three-times-after-police-hit-her-with-a-blast-ball |publisher=KUOW |date=June 10, 2020 |language=en}}</ref> [[stun grenade|flash bangs]], and [[pepper spray]].<ref>{{Cite web|last=Beekman|first=Daniel|last2=Brownstone|first2=Sydney|date=2020-06-08|title=Seattle council members vow ‘inquest’ into police budget; some say mayor should consider resigning|url=https://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/politics/seattle-council-members-vow-inquest-into-police-budget-some-say-mayor-should-consider-resigning/|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-06-17|website=[[The Seattle Times]]|language=en-US}}</ref> By June 7, police were placing barricades around the precinct and boarding up its windows.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2020-06-07|title=Seattle-area protests: Live updates for Sunday, June 7|url=https://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/seattle-area-protests-live-updates-for-sunday-june-7/|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-06-17|website=[[The Seattle Times]]|language=en-US}}</ref> Later that day, a car drove into a crowd of protesters, after which the driver shot a protester who had attempted to disarm him, before surrendering to police.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Green|first=Sara Jean|date=2020-06-10|title=Prosecutors say man who shot protester on Capitol Hill likely provoked the incident|url=https://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/crime/prosecutors-say-man-who-shot-protester-on-capitol-hill-likely-provoked-the-incident/|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-06-17|website=The Seattle Times|language=en-US}}</ref> The crowd outside the precinct grew and police, reporting that protesters were throwing bottles, rocks, and fireworks, were authorized to resume the use of tear gas shortly after midnight.<ref name=":1" /> Over 12,000 complaints were filed about the police response to the demonstrations, and members of the Seattle city council questioned how many weapons had in fact been thrown at the police.<ref name=":1">{{cite news |last1=Jimenez |first1=Esmy |last2=Raftery |first2=Isolde |title='They gave us East Precinct.' Seattle Police backs away from the barricade |url=https://www.kuow.org/stories/they-gave-us-east-precinct-seattle-police-backs-away-from-the-barricade |publisher=KUOW |date=June 8, 2020 |language=en |access-date=June 11, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200611041734/https://www.kuow.org/stories/they-gave-us-east-precinct-seattle-police-backs-away-from-the-barricade |archive-date=June 11, 2020 |url-status=live }}</ref>

The following afternoon, in a "police retreat,"<ref name="Stranger"/> the SPD abandoned the East Precinct. Protesters, initially suspicious of the police's motives, moved into the area, erected street barricades at a one-block radius from the station, and declared the area "Free Capitol Hill."<ref name="Stranger">{{Cite web |last1=Burns |first1=Chase |last2=Smith |first2=Rich |last3=Keimig |first3=Jasmyne |title=The Dawn of 'Free Capitol Hill' |work=[[The Stranger (newspaper)|The Stranger]] |date=June 9, 2020 |url=https://www.thestranger.com/slog/2020/06/09/43873501/the-dawn-of-free-capitol-hill |accessdate=June 11, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200611012121/https://www.thestranger.com/slog/2020/06/09/43873501/the-dawn-of-free-capitol-hill |archive-date=June 11, 2020 |url-status=live }}</ref>

== Territory ==
[[File:Welcome to CHAZ (50004505632).png|thumb|One of the zone's entrances on June 13, 2020]]
The zone is centered around the East Precinct building, a [[police precinct]] which the police abandoned on June 8.<ref name="Q13-Jun10">{{Cite AV media|url=https://q13fox.com/2020/06/10/protesters-take-over-streets-outside-abandoned-spd-east-precinct/|title=Protesters take over streets outside abandoned SPD East Precinct|date=June 9, 2020|last=Janavel|first=AJ|type=News report which aired 7:33am local time|language=|publisher=[[KCPQ]] (Q13)|access-date=June 11, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200611002124/https://q13fox.com/2020/06/10/protesters-take-over-streets-outside-abandoned-spd-east-precinct/|archive-date=June 11, 2020|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name="KIRO-Jun9">{{Cite web|last=Sun|first=Deedee|date=June 9, 2020|title=Armed protesters protect East Precinct police building after officers leave area|url=https://www.kiro7.com/news/local/armed-protesters-protect-east-precinct-police-building-after-officers-leave-area/4FC5C34P25BUVHDAACD4IMLT5I/|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200611042349/https://www.kiro7.com/news/local/armed-protesters-protect-east-precinct-police-building-after-officers-leave-area/4FC5C34P25BUVHDAACD4IMLT5I/|archive-date=June 11, 2020|access-date=June 11, 2020|publisher=KIRO|language=en-US}}</ref> It stretches north to [[Denny Way|East Denny Way]], east to 13th Avenue, south to [[Pike Street|East Pike]], and west to [[Broadway (Seattle)|Broadway]]. The entirety of [[Cal Anderson Park]] falls inside of the zone.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://slate.com/technology/2020/06/seattle-capitol-hill-autonomous-zone-occupied-protest.html |title=What's Really Going On at Seattle's So-Called Autonomous Zone? |work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] |date=June 16, 2020 |accessdate=June 17, 2020 |author=Hu, Jane C. |quote=Activists turned police's barriers around and declared that the surrounding area—roughly 5½ city blocks, which includes a public park—would be for the people.}}</ref>

Protesters used blockades and fences to construct staggered barricades at intersections.<ref name="Q13-Jun10"/> The entrance of the zone's territory is marked by a barrier reading "You Are Entering Free Capitol Hill."<ref name="Stranger"/> Other signs declared "You are now leaving the USA."<ref name="Heavy"/> [[Spray paint]] renamed the occupied police station as the "Seattle People's Department East Precinct" amid [[anarchist symbols]] and graffiti.{{r|City Journal}}

On June 16, the city and representatives of CHAZ agreed on a footprint for the zone. The new layout was posted on Mayor Durkan's blog following the agreement.<ref name="SLOGReZone">{{cite web |last1=Smith |first1=Rich |title=City and CHOP Residents Agree on New Footprint |url=https://www.thestranger.com/slog/2020/06/16/43919450/city-and-chop-residents-agree-on-new-footprint |website=SLOG |publisher=The Stranger}}</ref> The blog entry states the reasoning for the agreement between the two parties: "The City is committed to maintaining space for community to come to together, protest and exercise their first amendment rights. Minor changes to the protest zone will implement safer and sturdier barriers to protect individuals in this area."<ref name="MayorZoneBlog">{{cite web |last1=Durkan |first1=Jenny |title=City of Seattle Engages with Capitol Hill Organized Protest to make Safety Changes |url=https://durkan.seattle.gov/2020/06/city-of-seattle-responds-to-the-capitol-hill-organized-protest/ |website=Office of the Mayor |publisher=City Of Seattle}}</ref> As part of the agreement the city agreed to remove the old barriers and replace them with concrete along the new agreed-upon zone boundaries.<ref name="SLOGReZone"></ref>

On June 18, [[NPR]] reported, "Nobody inside the protest zone thinks a police return would end peacefully. Small teams of armed antifascists are also present, self-proclaimed community defense forces who say they're ready to fight if needed but that de-escalation is preferred."<ref name=Uneasy/>

== Internal governance ==
[[File:BLM Seattle on June 9, 2020 - 4.jpg|thumb|left|A [[sticker]] in the zone declaring "POLICE NOT WELCOME"]]

Occupants of the zone favor [[consensus decision-making]] instead of designating leaders who, according to one protester, can be "taken out"—killed or arrested.<ref name="ConsensusLeaders">{{cite web |last1=McNichols |first1=Joshua |title=CHAZ chews on what to do next |url=https://www.kuow.org/stories/chaz-community-chews-on-what-to-do-next |publisher=[[KUOW-FM]] |accessdate=13 June 2020}}</ref> Protesters hold frequent town halls to decide strategy and make plans.<ref name="WaPost-Trump">{{Cite web|last=Elfrin|first=Tim|date=2020-06-11|title='This is not a game': Trump threatens to 'take back' Seattle as protesters set up 'autonomous zone'|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/nation/2020/06/11/trump-seattle-autonomous-zone-inslee/|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200611153948/https://www.washingtonpost.com/nation/2020/06/11/trump-seattle-autonomous-zone-inslee/|archive-date=June 11, 2020|access-date=2020-06-11|website=Washington Post|language=en}}</ref> However, ''[[City Journal]]'' in a June 10 article claimed that former mayoral candidate [[Nikkita Oliver]] formulates the commune's political strategy.<ref name="City Journal"/> Seattle officials have not seen evidence of [[Antifa (United States)|Antifa]] umbrella groups organizing in the zone.{{r|otherwise}} On June 15, SPD Chief Best said, "There is no cop-free zone in the city of Seattle." Best indicated officers will go into the zone if there are threats to public safety: "I think that the picture has been painted in many areas that shows the city is under siege," she added. "That is not the case."<ref name=":0">{{cite web |url=https://apnews.com/39bb5494322351c2757bc8136271fe58 |title=Chief says 'no cop-free zone' in Seattle during protests |publisher=[[Associated Press]] |date=June 16, 2020 |accessdate=June 16, 2020}}</ref>

''[[The Seattle Times]]'' has referred to demonstrations in the area as the "Capitol Hill Occupied Protest" and the "Capitol Hill Organized Protest" (CHOP),<ref name="CHOP">{{cite news |date=June 13, 2020 |title=Seattle-area protests: Live updates on Saturday, June 13 |url=https://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/seattle-area-protests-live-updates-on-saturday-june-13/ |work=The Seattle Times |accessdate=June 13, 2020}}</ref> with [[NBC News]] saying CHAZ is "part protest, part commune."<ref name="PPPC"/> Reports describe the zone's structure as a cross between [[Occupy Wall Street]] and an independent [[student housing cooperative]]. Occupants have said their intentions are to create a neighborhood [[Police abolition movement|without police]] and a society where the police are no longer necessary.<ref name="Wobbly">{{anchor|CITEREFJames2020}}{{cite web|url=https://industrialworker.org/the-birth-of-the-capitol-hill-autonomous-zone|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20200610164217/https://industrialworker.org/the-birth-of-the-capitol-hill-autonomous-zone/|archive-date=June 10, 2020|title=The Birth of the Capitol Hill Autonomous Zone|author=James, J. F.|work=[[Industrial Worker]]|publisher=[[Industrial Workers of the World]]|date=June 9, 2020|accessdate=June 9, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.foxnews.com/us/seattle-protesters-declare-cop-free-zone-after-police-leave-precinct|title=Seattle protesters declare 'cop free zone' after police leave precinct|author=Ruiz, Michael|publisher=[[Fox News]]|date=June 9, 2020|accessdate=June 10, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200610022947/https://www.foxnews.com/us/seattle-protesters-declare-cop-free-zone-after-police-leave-precinct|archive-date=June 10, 2020|url-status=live}}</ref> Protesters have accepted the [[Open carry in the United States|open carry of firearms]] as a provision of safety.<ref name="The Cut overview">{{Cite web |last1=Read |first1=Bridget |title=What's Going On in CHAZ, the Seattle Autonomous Zone? |publisher=[[The Cut (website)|The Cut]] |date=2020-06-11 |url=https://www.thecut.com/2020/06/whats-going-on-in-chaz-the-seattle-autonomous-zone.html |language=en-us |accessdate=2020-06-12 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Members of the self-described [[Anti-fascism|anti-fascist]], [[Anti-racism|anti-racist]], and [[Labor rights|pro-worker]] [[Puget Sound John Brown Gun Club]] (PSJBGC) were reported on June 9 as carrying rifles in the zone.<ref name="Stranger"/><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.dailydot.com/debug/seattle-autonomous-zone-protests/ |title=Seattle protesters set up a barricaded 'cop-free zone' |work=[[The Daily Dot]] |date=June 9, 2020 |accessdate=June 10, 2020 |author=Thalen, Mikael |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200610030608/https://www.dailydot.com/debug/seattle-autonomous-zone-protests/ |archive-date=June 10, 2020 |url-status=live }}</ref> Although the zone fell within<ref name="CHAZ has armed guards">{{cite web |url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/seattles-capitol-hill-autonomous-zone-chaz-has-armed-guards |title=Meet the Gun Club Patrolling Seattle's Leftist Utopia |work=[[The Daily Beast]] |date=June 14, 2020 |accessdate=June 14, 2020 |author=Kelly, Kim}}</ref><!-- EDITORS: "The Daily Beast is considered generally reliable for news" per https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Reliable_sources/Perennial_sources#Sources --> the restricted area subject to Mayor Durkan's May 30 emergency order prohibiting the use of weapons including guns,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://durkan.seattle.gov/2020/05/mayor-durkan-issues-emergency-orders-proclaiming-civil-emergency-due-to-demonstrations-and-banning-use-of-weapons-throughout-city/ |title=Mayor Durkan Issues Emergency Orders Proclaiming Civil Emergency Due to Demonstrations and Banning Use of Weapons Throughout City |publisher=[[Mayor of Seattle]] |date=May 30, 2020 |accessdate=June 14, 2020 |author=Hightower, Kamaria}}</ref> her ban did not mandate enforcement.<ref name="CHAZ has armed guards"/> ''[[The Washington Post]]'' reported on June 12 that PSJBGC was on site but with no weapons visible,<ref>{{cite web |work=[[The Washington Post]] |title=Seattle protesters struggle to determine what’s next for ‘autonomous zone’ as Trump lobs threats |date=June 12, 2020 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/nation/2020/06/12/seattle-autonomous-zone-capitol-hill/ }}</ref> and ''[[USA Today]]'' the same day reported that "no one appeared armed with a gun."<ref name=USAT200612 /> Reporters from a local Seattle-based [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] affiliate were chased out of the zone by occupants on June 9.<ref name=reason>{{cite web|url=https://reason.com/2020/06/10/seattle-protesters-establish-autonomous-zone-outside-evacuated-police-precinct/|title=Seattle Protesters Establish 'Autonomous Zone' Outside Evacuated Police Precinct — Is the Capitol Hill Autonomous Zone a brave experiment in self-government or just flash-in-the-pan activism?|author=Britschgi, Christian|work=[[Reason (magazine)|Reason]]|date=June 10, 2020|accessdate=June 10, 2020}}</ref>

Volunteers within the area have formed an informal group to provide security, with an emphasis on de-escalation tactics and preventing vandalism.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Scruggs|first=Gregory|date=June 16, 2020|title=This Seattle protest zone is police-free. So volunteers are stepping up to provide security.|work=[[The Washington Post]]|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2020/06/16/this-seattle-protest-zone-is-police-free-so-volunteers-are-stepping-up-provide-security/|url-status=live|access-date=June 16, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Keimig|first=Jasmyne|date=June 16, 2020|title=Working the Night Shift at CHOP|url=https://www.thestranger.com/slog/2020/06/16/43915852/working-the-night-shift-at-chop|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-06-16|website=[[The Stranger (newspaper)|The Stranger]]|language=en}}</ref> On June 17, however, ''[[News.com.au]]'' said "the lack of proper policing may be giving criminals food for thought," and reported a "disturbingly detailed plan" on social media "to lure and attack vulnerable young women inside Seattle's lawless zone," which "has left the city's women terrified." The Seattle resident who made the social media post thereafter claimed it was a "dramatisation" meant to provoke a reaction. The Australian website also said footage had emerged "of a hip-hop artist handing out guns to strangers from the [[Trunk (car)|boot]] of his Tesla."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.news.com.au/world/north-america/sick-social-media-post-suggests-preying-on-young-women-in-seattles-lawless-zone/news-story/e2834cb3f22675b3cf6a556025372e45 |title=Sick social media post suggests 'preying on young women' in Seattle's lawless zone |work=[[News.com.au]] |date=June 17, 2020 |accessdate=June 17, 2020 |author=Graham, Ben}}</ref> Seattle's [[KIRO-TV]] quoted an eight-year tenant of an apartment near the East Precinct as saying, "We are just sitting ducks all day. Now every criminal in the city knows they can come into this area and they can do anything they want as long as it isn't life-threatening, and the police won't come in to do anything about it."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.kiro7.com/news/local/were-sitting-ducks-here-tenants-protest-zone-asking-spd-resume-response-crimes/MSRAGTVVDVDPBL22YNWNY6ZAWE/ |title="We're sitting ducks in here": Tenants in protest zone asking SPD to resume response to crimes |publisher=[[KIRO-TV]] |date=June 16, 2020 |accessdate=June 16, 2020 |author=Horcher, Gary}}</ref> Frustrated by blocked streets, criminal behavior, and lawlessness, some residents have temporarily moved out and others have installed security cameras. A man who said he "100 percent" supports the protest told [[KOMO-TV]]: "I don't even feel safe anymore."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://komonews.com/news/local/tensions-in-capitol-hill-as-residents-protesters-clash-over-access |title=Tensions in Capitol Hill mount as residents, protesters clash over access, crime |publisher=[[KOMO-TV]] |date=June 17, 2020 |accessdate=June 17, 2020 |author=Mutasa, Tammy}}</ref>

=== Demands ===
[[File:Black Lives Matter Shrine CHAZ Seattle WA.jpg|thumb|Shrine to victims of police brutality located around the corner from the abandoned SPD East Precinct]]

On June 9, 2020, a blog post containing a list of 30 demands appeared on [[Medium (website)|Medium]], including abolition of the Seattle Police Department and the court system; [[defund the police|defunding the SPD]] and reallocating those funds to [[community health]]; banning police use of firearms, batons, riot shields, and chemical agents; immediately releasing prisoners serving time for [[Cannabis (drug)|marijuana]]-related offenses or resisting arrest, with [[expungement]] of their records; mandatory retrials for people of color who are serving sentences for violent crimes; and [[prison abolition]]. Other demands included reforming education to increase the focus on [[African Americans|black]] and [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] history; free college; and free public housing.<ref name="Daily Dot demands">{{cite web |url=https://www.dailydot.com/debug/seattle-capitol-hill-autonomous-zone-demands/ |title=Seattle's 'Autonomous Zone' releases list of demands |work=[[The Daily Dot]] |date=June 10, 2020 |accessdate=June 10, 2020 |author=Thalen, Mikael |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200610234919/https://www.dailydot.com/debug/seattle-capitol-hill-autonomous-zone-demands/ |archive-date=June 10, 2020 |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name="Newsweek demands">{{cite web|url=https://www.newsweek.com/list-demands-seattle-autonomous-zone-includes-black-doctors-black-patients-end-prisons-1510323|work=[[Newsweek]]|title=List of Demands in Seattle 'Autonomous Zone' Includes Black Doctors for Black Patients, End to Prisons|author=Fink, Jenni|date=June 11, 2020|accessdate=June 11, 2020}}</ref> There was reportedly internal debate within the area over how many demands the commune should be putting forward, as some believe this is the start of a larger revolution while others believe police brutality should stay the immediate focus.<ref name="Free Food">{{cite news |last1=Baker |first1=Mike |title=Free Food, Free Speech and Free of Police: Inside Seattle's 'Autonomous Zone' |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/11/us/seattle-autonomous-zone.html |work=The New York Times |date=June 11, 2020 |access-date=June 11, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200611111536/https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/11/us/seattle-autonomous-zone.html |archive-date=June 11, 2020 |url-status=live }}</ref>

On June 10, approximately 1,000 protesters marched to the Seattle City Hall demanding the resignation of Mayor Durkan.<ref name="SelfDeclared01" /><ref>{{Cite web|last=Smith|first=Rich|last2=Keimig|first2=Jasmyne|date=June 10, 2020|title=Sawant Marches Through City Hall with Demonstrators Demanding Mayor Durkan's Resignation|url=https://www.thestranger.com/slog/2020/06/09/43880885/sawant-marches-through-city-hall-with-demonstrators-demanding-mayor-durkans-resignation|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-06-17|website=[[The Stranger (newspaper)|The Stranger]]|language=en}}</ref>

== Culture and amenities ==
[[File:Capitol Hill Autonomous Zone Black Lives Matter Mural 2.jpg|thumb|left|Street mural in the zone created by local artists depicting the message "[[Black Lives Matter]]"]]
Organizers pitched tents next to the former precinct in order to hold the space. They established the No Cop Co-op on June 9, offering free water, hand sanitizer, snacks donated by the community, and [[kebab]]s. Stalls were set up which offered cuisine such as [[vegan]] curry while others collected donations for the [[Homelessness in Seattle|homeless]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Buncombe|first=Andrew |date=June 12, 2020 |title=Seattle’s CHAZ: Inside the occupied vegan paradise – and Trump’s ‘ugly anarchist’ hell |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/seattle-chaz-occupied-protest-trump-vegan-washington-a9562066.html |work=[[The Independent]] |location= |access-date= June 13, 2020}}</ref> Two medical stations were established in the zone — the stations deliver basic health care to the homeless and [[sex worker]]s.<ref name="Aljazeera">{{cite web|url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/06/seattle-project-cop-free-world-200612213944832.html|title=In Seattle, a 'project' toward a cop-free world|work=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=June 12, 2020|accessdate=June 12, 2020|author=Morse, Ian}}</ref> The intersection of 12th and Pine was converted to a square for [[teach-in]]s, where a microphone was used to encourage people who were there "to fuck shit up" to go home. An outdoor cinema with a sound system and projector was set up<ref name="Stranger2"/> and used to screen open-air movies. The first film shown was ''[[13th (film)|13th]]'', [[Ava DuVernay]]'s documentary about racism and mass incarceration.<ref name="Stranger2">{{cite news |last1=Burns |first1=Chase |title=The Capitol Hill Autonomous Zone Renames, Expands, and Adds Film Programming |url=https://www.thestranger.com/slog/2020/06/10/43880223/the-capitol-hill-autonomous-zone-renames-expands-and-adds-film-programming |work=The Stranger |date=June 10, 2020 |language=en |access-date=June 10, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200610170143/https://www.thestranger.com/slog/2020/06/10/43880223/the-capitol-hill-autonomous-zone-renames-expands-and-adds-film-programming |archive-date=June 10, 2020 |url-status=live }}</ref> The [[Seattle Department of Transportation]] provided [[portable toilet]]s.<ref name="Stranger2"/>

The Marshall Law Band, a Seattle-based hip-hop fusion group, has performed for protesters.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Rietmulder|first=Michael|date=2020-06-17|title=Meet CHOP’s original house band: Seattle’s Marshall Law Band soundtracks a movement|url=https://www.seattletimes.com/entertainment/music/meet-chops-original-house-band-seattles-marshall-law-band-soundtracks-a-movement/|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-06-17|website=[[The Seattle Times]]|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Keimig|first=Jasmyne|date=June 16, 2020|title=Flash Bangs and Tear Gas Did Not Stop Marshall Law Band From Playing|url=https://www.thestranger.com/slog/2020/06/16/43920070/flash-bangs-and-tear-gas-did-not-stop-marshall-law-band-from-playing|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-06-17|website=[[The Stranger (newspaper)|The Stranger]]|language=en}}</ref>

<!--Don't add photo of pink umbrella-->
The city is still providing services to the area, including trash removal and [[Fire department|fire and rescue services]]; the SPD has also said they will respond to 9-1-1 calls within the area.<ref name="reason" /> On June 15, KIRO-TV reported a break-in and fire at an auto shop located near the zone, to which the SPD did not respond;<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.kiro7.com/news/local/nobody-showed-up-911-calls-bring-no-response-after-break-auto-shop-near-capitol-hill-protest-zone/O42CQ6VUXVDBHIB3334DI7LPV4/|title=“Nobody showed up”: 911 calls bring no response after break in at auto shop near Capitol Hill protest zone|author=Sun, Deedee|publisher=[[KIRO-TV]]|date=June 15, 2020|accessdate=June 16, 2020}}</ref> Police Chief Best later stated that officers observed the building from a distance and saw no sign of disturbance.<ref name=":0" />

[[File:Gardens at CHAZ Capital Hill Neighborhood Ccal anderson park.jpg|thumb|The zone's gardens, located in Cal Anderson Park, on June 13, 2020]]
A block-long street mural saying "[[Black Lives Matter]]" was painted June 10–11, located on [[Pine Street|East Pine Street]] between 10th and 11th Avenues.<ref>{{cite news |title=Huge Black Lives Matter mural in progress on Capitol Hill street |url=https://www.kiro7.com/news/local/huge-black-lives-matter-mural-progress-capitol-hill-street/IZKMN75YQ5EQNM4UUIRC353ZXQ/ |publisher=KIRO 7 News |date=June 11, 2020}}</ref> Visitors can light small candles and leave flowers at three shrines, which feature photographs and notes expressing sentiments related to [[George Floyd]] and other victims of police brutality.<ref name=USAT200612></ref><ref name="Shrine">{{cite web |last1=Hallie |first1=Golden |title=Seattle protesters take over city blocks to create police-free 'autonomous zone' |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2020/jun/11/chaz-seattle-autonomous-zone-police-protest |website=[[The Guardian]] |date=June 11, 2020 |accessdate=June 17, 2020 }}</ref>

[[Kitchen garden#Vegetable garden|Vegetable gardens]] have been planted by the occupants of Cal Anderson Park,<ref name="Gardens"/> with a farm also operating in the park where communards grow a variety of food products using donated seeds.<ref name="Gardens">{{cite web |last1=Baume |first1=Matt |title=Meet the Farmer Behind CHAZ's Vegetable Gardens |url=https://www.thestranger.com/slog/2020/06/12/43897621/meet-the-farmer-behind-chazs-vegetable-gardens |date=June 12, 2020|work=[[The Stranger (newspaper)|The Stranger]]|accessdate=13 June 2020}}</ref> ''The Seattle Times'' on June 11 reported that restaurant owners in the area had an uptick in walk-up business and a concomitant reduction in delivery costs.<ref name="Times-Jun11Live" /> However, on June 14, ''USA Today'' reported that most businesses in the zone had closed, "although a liquor store, ramen restaurant and taco joint are still doing brisk business."<ref name="USA Today in the Zone">{{cite web |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2020/06/14/inside-seattle-autonomous-zone-black-protesters-seek-lasting-change/3179232001/ |title=In Seattle's Capitol Hill autonomous protest zone, some Black leaders express doubt about white allies |work=[[USA Today]] |date=June 14, 2020 |accessdate=June 14, 2020 |author=Hughes, Trevor}}</ref>

== Reactions==
=== Local ===
Mayor Jenny Durkan called the creation of the zone an attempt to "de-escalate interactions between protestors and law enforcement,"<ref>{{Cite web|last=Mazza|first=Ed|date=June 11, 2020|title=Politicians Tell Trump To Go Back To The Bunker After His Threat To ‘Take Back’ Seattle|url=https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/politics/politicians-tell-trump-to-go-back-to-the-bunker-after-his-threat-to-take-back-seattle/ar-BB15kw8q|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-06-17|website=www.msn.com}}</ref> while Seattle Police Chief [[Carmen Best]] said that her officers would look at different approaches to "reduce [their] footprint" in the Capitol Hill neighborhood.<ref name="KIROFM">{{cite web|url=https://mynorthwest.com/1930871/seattle-protest-updates-tuesday/|title=Live updates: Protesters establish 'Free Capitol Hill' near East Precinct|work=MyNorthwest|publisher=[[KIRO-FM]]|date=June 9, 2020|accessdate=June 9, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200609170654/https://mynorthwest.com/1930871/seattle-protest-updates-tuesday/|archive-date=June 9, 2020|url-status=live}}</ref> [[Seattle City Council]] member [[Kshama Sawant]] (a politician from the [[Socialist Alternative (United States)|Socialist Alternative]]) spoke to the occupants of Cal Anderson Park on June 8.<ref name="Stranger" /> She called for the protesters to turn the precinct into a [[community center]] for [[restorative justice]].<ref name="Stranger2" /><ref>{{Cite web|last=Vansynghel|first=Margo|last2=Kroman|first2=David|date=June 17, 2020|title=The future of Capitol Hill's protest zone may lie in Seattle history|url=https://crosscut.com/2020/06/future-capitol-hills-protest-zone-may-lie-seattle-history|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-06-17|website=[[Crosscut.com]]|language=en}}</ref>

On June 10, Assistant Police Chief Deanna Nollette said in a news conference, "We're trying to get a dialogue going so we can figure out a way to resolve this without unduly impacting the citizens and the businesses that are operating in that area." She said police had received reports that "armed individuals" were running barricades set up by protesters as checkpoints, "intimidat[ing] community members," and that police had "heard anecdotally" of residents and businesses being asked to pay a fee to operate in the area, adding, "This is the crime of [[extortion]]."<ref name="Return">{{cite web |url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/06/11/us/seattle-police-autonomous-zone/index.html |title=Seattle police want to return to vacated precinct in what protesters call an 'autonomous zone' |publisher=[[CNN]] |date=June 11, 2020 |accessdate=June 11, 2020 |last1=Andone |first1=Dakin |last2=Rose |first2=Andy}}</ref> The following day, Best said the police had not received "any formal reports" of extortion, and the [[Greater Seattle Business Association]] said they "found no evidence of this occurring."<ref name="Times-Jun11Live">{{Cite web|last=Long|first=Katherine K.|date=2020-06-11|title=Live: Seattle-area protest updates: No police reports filed about use of weapons to extort Capitol Hill businesses, Best says|url=https://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/seattle-area-protests-updates-for-thursday-june-11/#update-12846417|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-06-12|website=The Seattle Times|language=en-US}}</ref>

On June 11, the SPD announced their desire to re-enter the abandoned East Precinct building, and said they still operate within the zone's territory.<ref name="Return"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://time.com/5851774/seattle-police-capitol-hill-autonomous-zone/|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|title=Seattle Protestors Are Occupying 6 City Blocks As An 'Autonomous Zone.' Some Fear a Police Crackdown Is Imminent|author=Clark, Peter A.|date=June 11, 2020|accessdate=June 11, 2020}}</ref> [[Governor of Washington|Governor]] [[Jay Inslee]], on the same day, said the zone was "unpermitted" but "largely peaceful."<ref name="otherwise">{{Cite web|last=Darcy|first=Oliver|date=2020-06-11|title=Right-wing media says Antifa militants have seized part of Seattle. Local authorities say otherwise|url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/06/11/media/seattle-antifa-protest-trump/index.html|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-06-12|publisher=[[CNN]]}}</ref>

On June 12, Police Chief Best said, "Rapes, robberies and all sorts of violent acts have been occurring in the area and we have not been able to get to it."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2020/06/12/seattle-mayor-tells-trump-go-back-bunker-escalation-tensions/ |title=Trump threatens to retake Seattle from 'domestic terrorists' as police hand district to protesters |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=June 12, 2020 |accessdate=June 12, 2020 |author=Sabur, Rozina}}</ref><!-- EDITORS: "There is consensus that The Daily Telegraph (also known as The Telegraph) is generally reliable." See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Reliable_sources/Perennial_sources#Sources --> In the early morning hours of June 12, an unknown man set a fire at the East Precinct building and walked away; community residents extinguished the flames before they could spread beyond the building's external wall or to the nearby tents.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://spdblotter.seattle.gov/2020/06/12/detectives-need-public-to-help-identify-east-precinct-arson-suspect/ |title=Detectives Need Help Identifying East Precinct Arson Suspect |website=SPD Blotter |date=June 12, 2020 |accessdate=June 17, 2020}}</ref> Later that day, Mayor Durkan visited the zone and told a [[The New York Times|''New York Times'']] reporter that she did not know of any serious crime that was reported in the area.<ref>{{Cite news|date=2020-06-13|title=Live Updates on George Floyd Protests: Judge Is Assigned to Officers’ Murder Trial|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/12/us/protests-george-floyd-black-lives-matter.html|access-date=2020-06-13|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>

On June 16, a deal was struck between occupation representatives and the city to "rezone" the occupied area to allow better street access for businesses and local services.<ref name="SLOGReZone"></ref>

On June 17, [[KING-TV]] reported that some are frustrated with the occupation of the area near their homes. One couple commented: "What you want from a home is a stress-free environment. You want to be able to sleep well, you want to feel comfortable and we just don't feel comfortable right now."  KING-TV reported also receiving anonymous emails from other local residents expressing "real concerns".<ref name="K5homeback">{{cite web |last1=Robertson |first1=Sebastian |title=Frustrated residents near Seattle's 'CHOP' zone want their neighborhood back |url=https://www.king5.com/article/news/local/frustrated-residents-near-seattles-chop-zone-want-their-neighborhood-back/281-b4c94c67-9183-4c8f-91ef-7371c86fe5f7 |publisher=[[KING-TV]]}}</ref>

On June 18, unease was reportedly being expressed by many black protesters about the zone and its use of Black Lives Matter slogans. According to NPR, "Black activists say there must be follow-through to make sure their communities remain the priority in a majority-white protest movement whose camp has taken on the feel of a neighborhood block party that's periodically interrupted by chants of "Black Lives Matter!"<ref name=Uneasy>{{cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/2020/06/17/879041066/seattle-strangers-discuss-racial-injustice-while-protesting |title='Remember Who We're Fighting For': The Uneasy Existence Of Seattle's Protest Camp |publisher=[[NPR]] |date=June 18, 2020 |accessdate=June 18, 2020 |author=Allam, Hannah}}</ref>

=== National ===
{{Tweet|name=[[Donald Trump|Donald J. Trump]]|username=realDonaldTrump|date=June 11, 2020|text=Radical Left Governor @JayInslee and the Mayor of Seattle are being taunted and played at a level that our great Country has never seen before. Take back your city NOW. If you don’t do it, I will. This is not a game. These ugly Anarchists must be stopped IMMEDIATELY. MOVE FAST!|ID=1271142274416562176|image=Trump POTUS Twitter icon.jpg}}
On June 9, [[United States Senate|U.S. Senator]] [[Ted Cruz]] from [[Texas]] stated that the zone was "endangering people's lives."<ref name="reason" /> The next day, President Donald Trump demanded that Governor Inslee and Mayor Durkan "take back" the zone, saying that if they did not do it, he would do it for them.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/chaz-seattle-trump-thread-take-back-capitol-hill-autonomous-zone/ |title=Trump threatens to "take back" Seattle's autonomous zone if leaders don't act: "This is not a game" |publisher=[[CBS News]] |date=June 12, 2020 |accessdate=June 12, 2020 |author=Watson, Kathryn}}</ref> Inslee condemned Trump's involvement in the situation, telling him to "stay out of Washington state's business."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://thehill.com/homenews/state-watch/502241-inslee-calls-on-trump-to-stay-out-of-washington-states-business|title=Inslee calls on Trump to 'stay out of Washington state's business'|work=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]|author=Coleman, Justine|date=June 11, 2020|accessdate=June 11, 2020}}</ref> Trump followed up by calling the protesters "[[Domestic terrorism in the United States|domestic terrorists]]."<ref name="WaPost-Trump" /> Durkan told President Trump to "go back to [his] [[Presidential Emergency Operations Center|bunker]]."<ref name="Free Food"/> On June 11, Durkan responded further: "Unfortunately, our president wants to tell a story about domestic terrorists who have a radical agenda and are promoting a conspiracy that fits his law and order initiatives. It's simply not true. Lawfully gathering and expressing first amendment rights, demanding we do better as a society, and providing true equity for communities of color is not terrorism. It's patriotism."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://patch.com/washington/seattle/whats-next-capitol-hill-autonomous-zone-unclear |title=What's Next For The 'Capitol Hill Autonomous Zone' Is Unclear |publisher=[[Patch (website)|Patch]] |date=June 11, 2020 |accessdate=June 11, 2020 |author=Combos, Lucas}}</ref>

''USA Today'' described the zone as a "protest haven."<ref name=USAT200612>{{cite news |title=CHAZ, a 'no Cop Co-op': Here's what Seattle's Capitol Hill Autonomous Zone looks like |first=Ryan W. |last=Miller |work=[[USA Today]] |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2020/06/12/seattle-protest-chaz-capitol-hill-autonomous-zone-police-free/3173968001/ |date=June 12, 2020}}</ref> [[Conservatism in the United States|Conservative]] [[pundit]] [[Guy Benson]] mocked the occupation of Capitol Hill as "[[communism|communist]] [[cosplay]]."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.foxnews.com/media/guy-benson-seattle-protesters-playing-make-believe|title=Guy Benson calls out Seattle protesters for 'playing make-believe,' 'Communist cosplay in the streets'|publisher=[[Fox News]]|date=June 11, 2020|accessdate=June 11, 2020|author=Garcia, Victor}}</ref> ''[[National Review]]'' contrasted the [[mainstream media]] coverage of the zone, which they deemed as sympathetic, to the negative coverage of the [[Malheur National Wildlife Refuge occupation|2016 Malheur National Wildlife Refuge occupation]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nationalreview.com/2020/06/nyt-and-wapo-fawn-over-seattle-autonomous-zone-anarchists/|title=NYT and WaPo Fawn Over Seattle Autonomous Zone Anarchists|author=Hoonhout, Tobias|date=June 12, 2020|accessdate=June 14, 2020|work=[[National Review]]}}</ref>

On June 12, the [[Fox News]] website published digitally altered photographs of the area, to include a man armed with an assault rifle from earlier Seattle protests; also added to the photographs were smashed windows from other parts of Seattle. In a separate incident, the Fox News website ran articles about protests in Seattle; however, the accompanying photo of a burning city was actually taken in [[Saint Paul, Minnesota]] the previous month.<ref name="Seattle Times">{{cite news |last1=Brunner |first1=Jim |title=Fox News runs digitally altered images in coverage of Seattle’s protests, Capitol Hill Autonomous Zone |url=https://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/politics/fox-news-runs-digitally-altered-images-in-coverage-of-seattles-protests-capitol-hill-autonomous-zone/ |work=The Seattle Times |date=June 15, 2020}}</ref> Although the area was mainly peaceful, "Fox's coverage contributed to the appearance of armed unrest", stated ''The Washington Post''. The manipulated and wrongly used images were removed, with Fox News stating that it "regrets these errors."<ref>{{cite news |last1=Stanley-Becker |first1=Isaac |title=Fox News removes manipulated images from coverage of Seattle protests |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2020/06/13/fox-news-removes-manipulated-images-coverage-seattle-protests/ |accessdate=June 15, 2020 |work=[[The Washington Post]] |date=June 14, 2020}}</ref> On June 15, [[Monty Python]] co-founder [[John Cleese]] mocked a Fox News [[anchorwoman]] for reading on air a [[Reddit]] post that purportedly indicated "signs of rebellion" within the zone, which turned out to be a joke referencing a scene from ''[[Monty Python and the Holy Grail]]''.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Blest |first1=Paul |title=Fox News Has Officially Lost Its Mind Over the Autonomous Zone in Seattle |url=https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/n7wz58/fox-news-has-officially-lost-its-mind-over-the-autonomous-zone-in-seattle |website=vice.com |publisher=Vice Media LLC |accessdate=15 June 2020}}</ref>

Protesters in other cities sought to replicate the autonomous zone in their own communities. Protesters in [[Portland, Oregon]] and in [[Asheville, North Carolina]] also tried to create autonomous zones but were stopped by the police.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2020-06-11|title=Portland abandons its own 'autonomous zone' day after establishing it|url=https://www.washingtonexaminer.com/news/portland-abandons-its-own-autonomous-zone-day-after-establishing-it|access-date=2020-06-13|website=Washington Examiner|language=en}}</ref><ref name=aaz>{{Cite web|date=2020-06-13|title=Asheville Autonomous Zone Short-Lived, But Protesters May Try Again|url=https://heavy.com/news/2020/06/asheville-autonomous-zone/|access-date=2020-06-13|website=Heavy.com|language=en|author=Stephanie Dube Dwilson}}</ref> On June 12, [[Tennessee]] [[Governor of Tennessee|Governor]] [[Bill Lee (Tennessee politician)|Bill Lee]] condemned the attempts to create an autonomous area in [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]],<ref name=naz>{{Cite web|date=2020-06-13|title=Nashville Autonomous Zone: Protesters Want to Create a Second CHAZ|url=https://heavy.com/news/2020/06/nashville-autonomous-zone/|access-date=2020-06-13|website=Heavy.com|language=en}}</ref> warning [[George Floyd protests in Tennessee|protesters in the state]] that "Autonomous zones, and violence will not be tolerated."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.foxnews.com/politics/tennessee-gov-lee-nashville-autonomous-zone|title=Tennessee Gov. Lee says Nashville autonomous zone won't ‘be tolerated’|author=McFall, Caitlin|publisher=[[Fox News]]|date=June 12, 2020|accessdate=June 12, 2020}}</ref> In [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania|Philadelphia]], a group established an encampment that has been compared to the Capitol Hill occupation; however, the primary focus is not autonomy but to protest Philadelphia's anti-homelessness laws.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2020-06-15|title=Officials Fear Growing Center City Encampment To Protest Homelessness Poses Health, Safety Threat|url=https://philadelphia.cbslocal.com/2020/06/15/officials-fear-growing-center-city-encampment-to-protest-homelessness-poses-health-safety-threat/|access-date=2020-06-16|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Rushing|first=Ellie|date=June 12, 2020|title=Philadelphians experiencing homelessness build protest encampment on Ben Franklin Parkway: ‘We all matter’|url=https://www.inquirer.com/news/philadelphia/philadelphia-protest-encampment-ben-franklin-parkway-tents-20200612.html|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-06-17|website=[[Philadelphia Inquirer]]|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Tanenbaum|first=Michael|date=June 16, 2020|title=Philly officials address encampment protest on Benjamin Franklin Parkway|url=https://www.phillyvoice.com/philly-encampment-protest-homeless-benjamin-franklin-parkway-housing-pha/|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-06-17|website=www.phillyvoice.com}}</ref>

On June 17, the [[United States House Committee on the Judiciary|U.S. House Judiciary Committee]] acrimoniously debated a major [[Police reform in the United States|police reform]] bill that marked Congress's first attempt to address the issue since George Floyd died in police custody. Seattle's Capitol Hill Autonomous Zone, ''Politico'' reported, "was a recurring theme throughout the proceedings." Rep. [[Debbie Lesko]] (R-Ariz.) offered an amendment to cut off federal police grants to any municipality that allows an autonomous zone. Rep. [[Pramila Jayapal]] (D-Wash.), whose district includes CHAZ, blamed Fox News and "right-wing media pundits" for spreading misinformation. The bill was eventually approved by a majority Democrat vote and is expected to pass in the full House, again along party lines. But it's unlikely to survive in the Republican-dominated Senate.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.politico.com/news/2020/06/17/judiciary-color-327023 |title=Antifa, Big Tech, and abortion: Republicans bring culture war to police brutality debate |work=[[Politico]] |date=June 17, 2020 |accessdate=June 17, 2020 |last1=Bresnahan |first1=John |last2=Ferris |first2=Sarah}}</ref>
